This is just a guess. I would imagine that a change in the Pituitary Gland (PG) would make a short person taller, if the change occurs before the bones harden at 25. The genetics would only tell the PG the amount of hormones to release. If you take genetics out and tell the PG to make more growth-stimulating hormones than the bones would respond accordingly. But, to reiterate, genetics tells the PG how much growth-stimulating hormones to release and even when to stop releasing them. Also, I'm pretty sure that the PG controls growth of other parts of the body, the skeleton being one of many. Again, this is just an educated guess based on my understanding of the Endocrine System.
This is situation is classical gigantism where the pituitary produces excess GH which causes epiphyseal growth before fusion and hence a taller individual is formed.

I think the reason why this myth came out is that many of the better powerlifters are short. This is because you don't need to get the weight up as high, which makes your life a lot easier. Secondly, eating a proportionate amount of food to fuel your muscle growth at over 6' is extremely difficult. For example, at 6'1 and 230 I need around 4400 calories. Keeping those clean is really, really hard. Basically, people confuse shortness as an effect of lifting, not an advantage for it.

...ignore the other guy who posted. It doesn't, that's a myth that people came up with a long time ago. Weight lifting forces a lot of your bones to become sturdier, and when done correctly actually makes you get bigger. Granted, if someone spends years doing squats that are far too heavy, your spinal bones/hip bones/leg bones will begin to grow thicker, but the chances of that actually stunting your growth are low. Think of it like this: football players lift all day, and pros are often >6'.

The same way basketball makes you taller. Your body adapts to the physical activity you're doing, and the earlier you begin, the more it affects the way you grow. For example gymnasts, who usually begin training very young (anywhere from 4 to 8) grow up to have wide shoulders and thicker necks because they need their upper body to be strong. Weight lifting exercises your muscles to be stronger and thicker, but it kinda helps gravity instead of favorizing your growth tall-wise.

Also, you have to think evolution-wise. Is it a big advantage and cost-effective to have a bony nose, instead of a cartilaginous one? Probably not. Imagine you got a blow to your nose and broke its "bones": the debris sent flying into your skull would probably hit your brain and could probably kill you faster compared to a cartilaginous nose. (Careful, even without a bony nose, an uppercut to your nose can force the ethmoid plate [behind your nose] upwards, into your brain)

See, it's stuff like the baculum that I find interesting to learn about, and would have liked to learn about such structures as they are found in the bodies of non-human mammals. Why the big fuss, guys? It's just a bone.

Cartilaginous tissue has many functions. One if such functions is to act as a "scaffold" for bone to grow, but it isn't its only function. It can also lubricate joints, preventing bones from touching (and degrading) each other, act as a supporting tissue, etc. The cartilage on your nose is supporting its structure, not working as a scaffold for bony growth.

Actually, studies have shown that supplemental calcium does NOT absorb as well as calcium occurring naturally in food. Milk is a good source, but broccoli and several other leafy green vegetables believe it or not work just as well (and with less calories).  PTH is not the only hormone involved in calcium regulation and trying blood concentration via ingestion will not necessarily work. Injection of PTH will likely cause mild immediate effects but in the long run not do anything at all.

The cells responsible for forming the outer layer of the tooth (which contain enamel) work on the outside of the tooth and they die as soon as the tooth erupts. Because of that, any enamel that may be damaged afterwards is not replaceable. Although the tooth protects itself by varying the layers of dentin beneath the damaged point, it is unable to restore the enamel and revert to its original state.
